column10: This topic covers the role unconscious bias can play in the workplace, as well as the importance of equality, diversity and inclusion.
column11:
You also learn about the equality laws that are in place, and the duty to treat our customers fairly. This diversity and inclusion topic contains 8 activities. You can do them all in one go or in stages. 
You must complete all 8 to finish this topic.
column12:
On completing all the topics, you’ll:
•        have an understanding of what unconscious bias is and how it can affect your work
•        be able to recognise different types of unconscious bias and their impact
•        know how to challenge your own thinking, and how to help create the right environment.
•        be aware of some of the strategies you can use to minimise the impact of unconscious bias on decision making
•        understand why we need legislation
•        be more aware of how stereotyping, bullying and harassment can affect work relationships and decisions
•        have insight into the barriers disabled customers may face and duties towards all of our customers

column10: This topic is for everyone who handles information and needs to share and protect it.
column11:
It covers government security classifications, the role of an information asset owner, how to keep information safe away from the office and how to recognise online threats and fraud.
This e-learning topic has 7 activities. You can do them all in one go or in stages. You must complete all 7 to finish this topic.
column12:
On completing all 7 activities in this topic, you’ll:
•        understand how security classifications help protect information
•        know your responsibilities when protecting and sharing information both inside and outside of government
•        be more confident when managing the risks of handling and disposing of information
•        be aware of the risks when working with information away from the office
•        be able to guard against email and other online threats
•        be better informed about your responsibilities in recognising and preventing fraud and bribery
•        understand how to manage any risks to a specific information asset you may own

column7: SPECIFIC SCORMS INC MOT/MOT/Government security classifications/p20672_3032017.zip

SPECIFIC SCORMS INC MOT/MOT/Managing information as an asset/p21459_3032017.zip

column10: Everyone needs to be able to identify, manage and control health and safety risks in the workplace.
column11: This e-learning topic contains 6 activities. You can do them all in one go or in stages. You must complete all 6 to finish this topic.
column12:
On completing all 6 activities in this topic, you’ll have learnt:
•        about the symptoms of stress, strategies to cope with it and how to escalate concerns about stress and its effects
•        what to do to prevent slips, trips and falls and how to raise awareness of dangers beyond your immediate control
•        how to use computer equipment correctly to avoid discomfort
•        that everyone must be aware of your department's health and safety policies and procedures
•        how to prevent fire and what to do in an emergency
•        whether you should attempt manual tasks and how to do them safely

column10: Develop your commercial thinking and learn how, through the effective preparation, procurement and management of services, value for money can be maximised.
column11: This topic highlights the benefit of commercial understanding when developing and implementing policy and programmes, and explains the role of commercial professionals and the stages of the commercial cycle.
column12:
On completing this topic, you'll understand the importance of:
•        commercial awareness and capabilities in building better public services across government 
•        support and guidance from commercial specialists 
•        value-for-money considerations when providing public services
column18:
Administrative level (AA/AO)
First line managers (EO)
Middle managers (HEO/SEO)
Senior managers (Grade 6/7)

column10: This topic helps you present yourself at your best when applying for another Civil Service role.
column11: Among the skills you learn is the ability to provide evidence of your strengths, competencies and transferable skills in a way that relates directly to the job specification. You are given a range of examples of applications and competency statements to review, rewrite and assess for appointment.
column12:
After completing this topic, you’ll:
•        be confident in putting yourself forward for new roles, even those outside of your grade and department
•        improve your chances of securing your next role
column18:
Administrative level (AA/AO)
First line managers (EO)
Middle managers (HEO/SEO)
Senior managers (Grade 6/7)

column10: This topic demonstrates how you can harness your emotional intelligence to increase your capability for leadership and relationship building.
column11:
During the learning activities, you are introduced to the 3 core concepts of emotional intelligence:
•        emotional awareness (knowing what feelings you, and others, have)
•        emotional literacy (expressing your feelings and understanding how others express theirs)
•        emotional honesty (being open about your emotions and creating an environment in which people feel safe to do the same)
column12:
After completing this topic, you'll be able to:
•        build productive relationships 
•        make better decisions
•        motivate your colleagues
column15:
Active listening
Brene Brown on empathy
Emotional intelligence has 12 elements. Which do you need to work on? 
Key skills for raising emotional intelligence

column10: This topic for customer-facing staff helps you identify the benefits of communicating effectively with external and internal customers.
column11: It covers effective written and verbal communication, as well as techniques for the telephone and for digital platforms. You also learn about active listening.
column12:
On completing this online learning, you'll be able to:
•        describe effective techniques for communicating with customers face-to-face and at a distance
•        plan and structure communications to ensure successful outcomes
•        adapt your communication style to different types of customers and understand how to identify the different needs of your external and internal customers

column10: This topic improves your understanding of mental health issues and the impact they can have if they remain unaddressed.
column11: You find out how to help colleagues who may have a mental health condition and when you should direct them to seek professional support. By becoming more knowledgeable and empathetic, you should feel more confident in starting, encouraging and promoting open conversations about the effects of mental ill health.
column12:
After completing this topic, you'll:
•        feel more confident in your ability to support colleagues with mental health conditions within your team.
•        be able to create an inclusive environment within which issues connected to mental health can be openly discussed and addressed

column2: Collaboration across departments, government and beyond
column10: Discover the essential skills and behaviours that underpin successful collaboration, such as building and maintaining relationships and sharing control.
column11: In this introductory topic, you learn about the value of collaboration, how to articulate a shared vision for collaboration and how to maximise the benefits it brings. By being mindful of your partners’ interests and ambitions, you can help ensure that collaboration objectives are met.
column12:
After completing this topic, you'll:
•        know how to get the most out of professional collaborative relationships
•        ensure that all parties are clear on their roles and responsibilities
•        contribute to improved sharing of best practice and innovative ideas
